grounding: The with no lysine (K) (WNK) kinases are an evolutionarily ancient group of kinases with atypical placement of the catalytic lysine and diverse physiological roles. Recent studies have shown that WNKs are directly regulated by chloride, potassium, and osmotic pressure. Here, we review the discovery of WNKs as chloride-sensitive kinases and discuss physiological contexts in which chloride regulation of WNKs has been demonstrated. These include the kidney, pancreatic duct, neurons, and inflammatory cells. We discuss the interdependent relationship of osmotic pressure and intracellular chloride in cell volume regulation. We review the recent demonstration of potassium regulation of WNKs and speculate on possible physiological roles. Finally, structural and mechanistic aspects of intracellular ion and osmotic pressure regulation of WNKs are discussed.

Recent studies have highlighted the importance of intracellular ion control in modulating WNK activity, particularly through the coordinated action of potassium channels (NKCC and KCC) and the SPAK kinase. In the Malpighian tubule, a key ion transport organ in insects, ion fluxes are tightly regulated by WNK signaling, influencing both fluid and electrolyte balance. Disruption of this delicate balance can lead to inflammatory responses, mediated by the activation of the inflammasome. This review aims to summarize the current understanding of the intricate relationships between ion transport, WNK signaling, and the Malpighian tubule, highlighting the potential implications for understanding ion homeostasis and inflammatory responses in various organisms.
